Green.usage: Lesson opening, knowledge retrieval, foundation setting
Green.cognitive_purpose: Activate prior knowledge and establish learning foundations

skills.example_question: What do we need to know before we start?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Help students recognize and name key elements before deeper exploration
teacher_instructions: Present materials or information for students to examine
Ask students to point out or name what they notice
Encourage detailed observation without judgment
Build vocabulary through identification activities
common_mistakes: Moving too quickly past the identification stage
Not giving students enough time to observe
Accepting vague descriptions instead of specific identification

Science.assessment_focus: Can students accurately identify and name scientific concepts?

Mathematics.assessment_focus: Can students identify mathematical concepts and relationships?

foundational.example: Point to the red objects in the classroom

developing.example: Identify living and non-living things in a nature photo

proficient.example: Identify bias in a historical source

skills.example_question: What did we learn last time that might help us now?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Activate prior knowledge to build connections with new learning
teacher_instructions: Create connections to previous lessons or experiences
Use prompts that help students access their memory
Allow think time for memory retrieval
Validate and build upon what students remember

Blue.usage: During exploration, when students need to sort/compare information
Blue.cognitive_purpose: Help students organize their thinking and make connections between ideas

skills.example_question: How can we group these things?
skills.description: Sort items into groups based on shared characteristics

framework_guidance.key_principle: Provide clear criteria for grouping and allow students to explain their reasoning
teacher_instructions: Give students items to sort (physical or conceptual)
Ask them to create their own categories first
Have students explain WHY they grouped items together
Discuss multiple valid ways to categorize the same items
student_scaffolds: I put this in this group since...
Another way to sort these would be...
common_mistakes: Focusing on surface features rather than meaningful connections

Science.assessment_focus: Can students identify scientific classification criteria?

Mathematics.assessment_focus: Can students use mathematical properties for grouping?

foundational.description: Sort concrete, familiar items with obvious differences
foundational.example: Sort classroom objects by color or size

developing.description: Sort items with multiple valid groupings

proficient.description: Create own classification system with sub-categories
proficient.example: Develop a classification system for school subjects

skills.example_question: How are these two things the same?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Focus on both similarities AND differences to deepen understanding
teacher_instructions: Provide two or more items/concepts to compare
Ask for both similarities and differences
Use graphic organizers to structure the comparison
Discuss which similarities/differences are most significant

Yellow.usage: Mid-lesson comprehension checks, when students need to justify thinking
Yellow.cognitive_purpose: Develop analytical thinking and evidence-based reasoning

skills.example_question: Can you explain what's happening here?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Support clear communication of understanding with appropriate detail
teacher_instructions: Ask open-ended questions that require explanation
Provide sentence starters to support explanation
Encourage students to include evidence in their explanations
Model clear explanation techniques

skills.example_question: What evidence do you have to support this?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Require students to back up their thinking with evidence

Orange.usage: When focus is on precise expression and academic language
Orange.cognitive_purpose: Develop academic language and precise communication skills

skills.example_question: Can you use this new word in a sentence?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Develop academic vocabulary through meaningful use in context
teacher_instructions: Introduce key vocabulary explicitly
Provide multiple opportunities to use new words
Connect vocabulary to concepts being learned
Encourage precise word choice

Red.usage: End of lesson, assessment, when students have solid foundation
Red.cognitive_purpose: Apply learning creatively and evaluate ideas critically

skills.example_question: What do you think will happen if we try this?

framework_guidance.key_principle: Encourage evidence-based predictions that can be tested
teacher_instructions: Present scenarios for prediction
Ask students to explain their reasoning
Provide opportunities to test hypotheses
Discuss outcomes and refine thinking
student_scaffolds: I think this will happen because...

skills.example_question: Which one do you think is the best?
skills.description: Form opinions and make decisions with justification

framework_guidance.key_principle: Require clear criteria and evidence for judgments
student_scaffolds: I think this is better because...
